item.title: How quickly can you convert floats to doubles (and back)?
item.description: Many programming languages have two binary floating-point types: float (32-bit) and double (64-bit). It reflects the fact that most general-purpose processors supports both data types natively. Often we need to convert between the two types. Both ARM and x64 processors can do in one inexpensive instructions. For example, ARM systems may use the fcvt instruction. … Continue reading How quickly can you convert floats to doubles (and back)?
item.author: (Published by)

item.title: What if your website had business hours? — Bobbie Chen
item.description: In "Being on-call sucks", I wrote about how having an on-call person or rotation is required for any software service running 24/7. While reviewing the draft, my friend Michael L. pointed out that while most websites are up all the time, some are not - for example, B&H Photo doesn't accept orders on Saturdays for religious reasons. So what if our software business had limited hours instead, like a physical-world store?
item.author: (Bobbie Chen)

item.description: I've been talking about zero-knowledge proofs (the "zk" part) for a while now, so I'm going to skip that and assume that you already know what "zk" is about. The first thing we need to define is: what's a virtual machine (VM)? In brief, it's a program that can run other programs, usually implemented as a loop that executes a number of given instructions (the other program). Simplified, a VM could ...

item.title: How to simplify your C# unit testing with a mocking framework
item.description: It’s time to take your unit testing to the next level. You’ve implemented either NUnit, or xUnit, or MSTest in your projects. You’ve gotten your code coverage to 80+%. But the are just some things that are hard to test or validate in your project. How do you test the “business logic” in your repository class? How do you test your dependent web service or database? Yeah, you can write special unit test and create fake objects to mimic these dependencies but why waste your time writing code that does not ship with the end product. Or write a lot of code with the ExcludeFromCoverage attribute :smile:. Well this is mocking comes in.
item.author: (Joseph Guadagno)
